title: Spelling Patterns — Double Consonant Words and Syllable Division
description: Students explore words with double consonants in the middle (rabbit, kitten, butter) and learn the syllable division rule: split between the double consonants. This helps with both reading long words and spelling them correctly.
instructions:
1. Present words with double consonants: rabbit, kitten, butter, happy, little, summer.
2. Clap the syllables: rab-bit, kit-ten, but-ter.
3. Notice: the syllable break falls BETWEEN the double consonants.
4. Explain: the double consonant keeps the first vowel short.
5. Practice dividing words at the double consonant.
6. Compare: diner (long i, one n) vs. dinner (short i, double n).
7. Write and sort words by pattern.
materials_needed: Scissors for cutting words at syllable breaks

slides.heading: Double Consonant Spelling
slides.subheading: Splitting Syllables Between Doubles

items: Word cards: rabbit, kitten, butter, happy, little, summer, dinner, puppy, letter, mitten, ladder, pepper, pillow, yellow, better, sitting
Scissors for cutting word cards at syllable breaks
slides.setup_instructions: Write words large on cards so they can be physically cut at the syllable break. Prepare comparison pairs: diner/dinner, later/latter, super/supper. Have the spelling journal open.

slides.text: Look at these words: RABBIT, KITTEN, BUTTER. They all have DOUBLE CONSONANTS in the middle (bb, tt, tt). Say them slowly: RAB-BIT, KIT-TEN, BUT-TER. Did you hear? Each word breaks into TWO syllables, and the break falls RIGHT BETWEEN the double consonants!

Why do these words have double consonants? Because the double consonant keeps the first vowel SHORT. Compare: DINER (long i, one n — a place to eat) vs. DINNER (short i, double n — the meal itself). LATER (long a, one t) vs. LATTER (short a, double t). The double consonant is a signal: the vowel before it is short!

The syllable division rule is your reading superpower: when you see a long word with double consonants in the middle, split between them! HAP-PY, LIT-TLE, SUM-MER, PEP-PER, YEL-LOW. This makes big words easy to read: UM-BREL-LA (double l), BAL-LOON (double l).

slides.prompt: Cut each word card between the double consonants to show the syllable break. Then in your spelling journal: 1) Write 12 double-consonant words, drawing a line between syllables. 2) Write 4 comparison pairs (like diner/dinner) and explain the vowel sound difference. 3) Write 4 sentences using double-consonant words. Circle the double consonants and mark the short vowel.

slides.text: Double consonants are spelling CLUES. When you see them, you know the vowel before them is short AND the syllable break is between them. When you are writing and need a short vowel sound in the first syllable, double the consonant! This pattern appears in hundreds of English words.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify syllable breaks at double consonants, explain why the first vowel is short, and spell 10+ double-consonant words correctly?

parent_notes: The syllable division rule for double consonants is extremely practical — it helps with both reading and spelling. Children who know this rule can decode unfamiliar multi-syllable words much more easily. The comparison pairs (diner/dinner) dramatically illustrate why double consonants matter. In everyday reading, pause at double-consonant words and have the child identify the syllable break. This metalinguistic awareness (knowing HOW English spelling works) builds lasting literacy skills beyond simple memorization.

title: Subtracting Like Fractions with Fraction Circles
description: Students learn to subtract fractions with the same denominator using fraction circle insets. They physically remove fraction pieces and record the subtraction equations, applying the rule: keep the denominator, subtract the numerators.
instructions:
1. Review adding like fractions.
2. Present subtraction: 3/4 - 1/4. Place 3 fourth-pieces, remove 1.
3. Count remaining: 2/4.
4. State the rule: keep the denominator, subtract the numerators.
5. Practice with various denominators.
6. Solve problems where the result equals zero: 3/3 - 3/3 = 0.
7. Mix addition and subtraction problems.

slides.heading: Subtracting Fractions
slides.subheading: Same Denominator — Removing Pieces

items: Montessori fraction circle insets (halves through tenths)
slides.setup_instructions: Set out fraction circle insets. Prepare subtraction problems with like denominators. Include problems that result in zero and problems mixed with addition.

slides.text: You can add fractions with the same denominator — now let us SUBTRACT them! Start: 3/4 - 1/4. Place 3 fourth-pieces in the circle frame. Now REMOVE 1 fourth-piece. How many remain? 2 pieces out of 4 = 2/4. So 3/4 - 1/4 = 2/4.

The rule is the same as addition, but with subtraction: keep the DENOMINATOR, SUBTRACT the numerators. 3/4 - 1/4: keep 4 on the bottom, subtract 3 - 1 = 2 on top. Answer: 2/4. Easy! The pieces are the same size, so you just count how many are left.

What about 3/3 - 3/3? Place 3 third-pieces. Remove all 3. Zero pieces left! 3/3 - 3/3 = 0. And what about 5/6 - 2/6? Place 5 sixth-pieces, remove 2. 3 remain. 5/6 - 2/6 = 3/6. Now let us mix addition and subtraction!

Word problem: 'A pie was cut into 8 slices. The family ate 5 slices. What fraction of the pie remains?' The whole pie = 8/8. They ate 5/8. Remaining: 8/8 - 5/8 = 3/8. Three-eighths of the pie is left!

slides.prompt: Solve with fraction circles: 1) 3/4 - 1/4, 2) 5/6 - 3/6, 3) 7/8 - 4/8, 4) 4/5 - 2/5, 5) 6/10 - 3/10. Word problems: 6) 'I had 3/4 of a cake. I ate 1/4. How much remains?' 7) 'A jar was 5/6 full. We used 2/6. How full is it now?' Draw each problem with fraction circles. Then solve 3 mixed problems (some addition, some subtraction).

slides.text: Adding and subtracting fractions with the same denominator follow one simple rule: keep the denominator, add or subtract the numerators. You now have complete command over like-fraction arithmetic! Remember to always check: is your answer less than or equal to 1 whole? If your numerator is bigger than your denominator, something went wrong!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child subtract like fractions using circles, solve subtraction word problems, and distinguish between fraction addition and subtraction problems?

parent_notes: Fraction subtraction with like denominators follows the same logic as addition — the physical act of removing pieces from the inset makes it intuitive. If the child finds it easy, introduce challenges: missing part problems ('? - 2/5 = 1/5, what is the missing fraction?') or problems that result in zero. These extend thinking naturally. The word problems are important because they show real applications. Point out fraction subtraction in everyday life: 'We had 3/4 of a watermelon, and we ate 1/4. How much is left?'

title: Medieval Life — Daily Life in a Castle and Village
description: Students compare the daily lives of castle inhabitants (lords, ladies, servants) with village peasants. They learn about food, clothing, entertainment, and the stark differences between rich and poor in medieval society.
instructions:
1. Describe a day in the life of a castle lord and lady.
2. Describe a day in the life of a village peasant.
3. Compare: food (feasts vs. bread and pottage), clothing (silk vs. wool), entertainment (tournaments vs. festivals).
4. Discuss the role of seasons: planting, harvest, winter.
5. Explore medieval food: no potatoes, tomatoes, or chocolate (those come from the Americas later!).
6. The child creates a comparison chart.
7. Write a diary entry from either perspective.

slides.heading: Medieval Daily Life
slides.subheading: Castle Lords and Village Peasants

items: Images of medieval castle life and village life
slides.setup_instructions: Display contrasting images: castle feasts vs. peasant meals, noble clothing vs. peasant clothing, tournaments vs. village festivals. Prepare comparison categories: food, clothing, housing, work, entertainment.

slides.text: A DAY AS A LORD: Wake at dawn in a stone chamber. Attend chapel for morning prayers. Breakfast: bread, cheese, ale. Morning: manage the estate, settle disputes, meet with knights. Midday: the main meal in the great hall — roasted meat, fish, bread, wine, served on trenchers (thick bread plates!). Afternoon: hunting with falcons or inspecting lands. Evening: entertainment in the great hall — music, storytelling, jesters.

A DAY AS A PEASANT: Wake before dawn in a one-room cottage with a dirt floor. Breakfast: bread and pottage (thick vegetable stew — the main food). Work ALL day: plowing fields, tending animals, mending fences, gathering wood. Midday meal: more pottage and bread. Evening: mend tools, spin wool by firelight. Church on Sundays was the main entertainment and social gathering.

The differences were enormous! Lords wore silk, fur, and colorful fabrics. Peasants wore rough wool and linen. Lords ate meat, spices, and sweets. Peasants ate bread, vegetables, and pottage — meat was rare and expensive. Lords lived in stone castles. Peasants lived in wooden or wattle-and-daub cottages with thatched roofs.

Surprising fact: medieval Europeans had NO potatoes, no tomatoes, no chocolate, no corn, no peppers, and no coffee! All of those came from the Americas after 1492. Their spices came from Asia along trade routes and were incredibly expensive — pepper was worth its weight in gold! Food was seasonal: fresh fruits in summer, preserved and dried foods in winter.

slides.prompt: Create a comparison chart with two columns: 'Castle Lord' and 'Village Peasant.' Compare: housing, food (breakfast, lunch, dinner), clothing, work, entertainment, and education. Illustrate each side with small drawings. Then write a diary entry for ONE day as either a castle lord or a village peasant. Include details about food, work, and how you feel about your life.

slides.text: Medieval life was vastly different depending on where you were born. The feudal system meant your birth determined your entire life — there was almost no way to change social class. Today we value equal opportunity and social mobility. Understanding how people lived in the past helps us appreciate and protect the freedoms we have now.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child compare castle and village life across 4 categories and describe 3 foods that medieval Europeans did NOT have?

parent_notes: Comparing castle and village life makes the feudal system concrete and personal. The diary entry exercise builds empathy across time and class. The food facts (no potatoes, tomatoes, chocolate) always surprise children and naturally lead to discussions about the Columbian Exchange (Age of Exploration, coming soon). If your child identifies with the peasant's hard life, that is healthy empathy. If they want to be the lord, discuss the responsibilities that came with privilege. Both lives had challenges; both had moments of joy.

title: Climate Zones — How Weather Patterns Shape Regions
description: Students learn that Earth has three main climate zones determined by latitude and distance from the equator. They explore the characteristics of tropical, temperate, and polar zones and connect climate to the biomes and civilizations they have studied.
instructions:
1. Review the equator, Tropics of Cancer and Capricorn, Arctic and Antarctic Circles.
2. Define climate zone: a region with consistent weather patterns over many years.
3. Present the three zones: tropical (near equator), temperate (middle latitudes), polar (near poles).
4. Describe each zone's characteristics: temperature, precipitation, seasons.
5. Connect to places studied: Amazon = tropical, Europe = temperate, Arctic = polar.
6. The child colors a world map showing the three zones.
7. Record in geography journal.

slides.heading: Climate Zones
slides.subheading: Tropical, Temperate, and Polar

items: World map showing latitude lines (equator, tropics, polar circles)
slides.setup_instructions: Display the world map with latitude lines clearly marked. Have the globe available to show how sunlight hits Earth at different angles. Prepare the blank map with latitude lines drawn in.

slides.text: Why is the Amazon hot and wet while Antarctica is frozen? The answer is CLIMATE ZONES. Earth's climate depends on how directly sunlight hits each area. Near the equator, sunlight hits DIRECTLY — it is hot! Near the poles, sunlight hits at a steep angle — it is cold! This creates three main climate zones.

TROPICAL ZONE (between Tropics of Cancer and Capricorn, about 23.5 degrees N and S): Hot year-round. Lots of rain. No real winter. Home to rainforests, savannas, and coral reefs. Places we have studied: Amazon Rainforest, central Africa. Average temperature: 77-86 degrees F all year.

TEMPERATE ZONE (between tropics and polar circles): Four distinct seasons — warm summers, cold winters, and spring and fall transitions. Moderate rainfall. Most of Europe, most of the US, and parts of South America and Asia are temperate. This is where most of the world's population lives!

POLAR ZONE (above Arctic Circle and below Antarctic Circle): Extremely cold year-round. Long, dark winters and short, light summers. In winter, the sun does not rise for months; in summer, it does not set! Ice caps, tundra, and very few plants grow here. Average temperature: well below freezing.

slides.prompt: Color your blank world map with the three climate zones: tropical (red/orange between the tropics), temperate (green/yellow between tropics and polar circles), and polar (blue/white above Arctic and below Antarctic circles). Label each zone and write its key characteristics. Then place these locations in the correct zone: Amazon, London, North Pole, Egypt, New York, Antarctica, India. In your journal, write: Which zone do YOU live in? What are your seasons like?

slides.text: Climate zones explain why the world is so diverse — different climates create different biomes, which support different plants, animals, and human cultures. The tropical zone has the most biodiversity. The temperate zone has the most people. The polar zones have the most extreme conditions. Understanding climate zones helps us understand our whole planet!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify the three climate zones on a map, describe their characteristics, and explain why distance from the equator affects temperature?

parent_notes: Climate zones are a fundamental geography concept that ties together many previous lessons: why the Amazon is a rainforest (tropical), why Europe has four seasons (temperate), and why polar bears live at the poles (polar). The globe demonstration is important — tilt the globe to show how sunlight angle changes with latitude. The concept of seasons being caused by Earth's tilt (not distance from the sun) can be introduced if the child is ready. Connect to your own location: 'We are in the temperate zone — that is why we have winter and summer!'

title: Read Aloud — Ramona Quimby, Age 8, Chapters 7-9
description: Continue reading Ramona Quimby as she faces family tensions, school challenges, and the universal childhood experience of wanting to be understood. Students discuss family dynamics, empathy, and how realistic fiction mirrors real life.
instructions:
1. Review chapters 4-6.
2. Read chapters 7-9 aloud.
3. Discuss the Quimby family's money worries — how does this affect Ramona?
4. Identify how Cleary shows (not tells) Ramona's feelings.
5. Discuss: How is Ramona similar to and different from you?
6. Practice finding similes or metaphors in Cleary's writing.
7. The child writes a letter to Ramona giving advice.
materials_needed: Ramona Quimby, Age 8 by Beverly Cleary

slides.heading: Ramona Quimby, Age 8
slides.subheading: Chapters 7-9: Family and Growing Up

items: Ramona Quimby, Age 8 by Beverly Cleary
slides.setup_instructions: These chapters deal with family tensions and money worries — sensitive topics that require thoughtful discussion. Read with empathy. Be prepared to discuss how families handle stress.

slides.text: Ramona's family is dealing with real-world problems: money is tight, her dad is going back to school, and everyone is stressed. Cleary does not hide these realities from young readers because she respects children enough to tell the truth. As we read, notice how family stress affects everyone — even the youngest member.

Watch for Beverly Cleary's technique of SHOWING rather than TELLING. She does not write 'Ramona was sad.' She shows Ramona kicking a rock, hiding under her covers, or snapping at Beezus. The reader figures out the emotion from the actions. This is powerful writing that trusts the reader!

Even though Ramona's life is very different from some of ours, her FEELINGS are universal: wanting to be noticed, wanting approval, feeling frustrated when things are not fair, loving your family even when they drive you crazy. That is why millions of people love this book — Ramona feels what WE feel.

slides.prompt: Write a letter TO Ramona, as if she were a real friend. Give her advice about her problems. Be kind and specific — what would you tell her about dealing with school? About her family's money worries? About getting along with Beezus? Use compound sentences and specific details from the book. Start with 'Dear Ramona,' and end with encouragement.

slides.text: Beverly Cleary shows us that everyday life — with all its problems, embarrassments, and small victories — is worth writing about. You do not need magic or adventure to tell a great story. Sometimes the most powerful stories are about a regular kid trying to be understood. That is the beauty of realistic fiction.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify Cleary's 'show don't tell' technique, discuss family themes with empathy, and write a thoughtful letter to the character?

parent_notes: These chapters address family financial stress, which is a real issue for many families. Cleary handles it honestly but with humor and hope. If your family has experienced financial stress, this can be a wonderful opening for conversation. If not, it builds empathy. The 'letter to Ramona' exercise develops perspective-taking and gives the child practice in giving kind, constructive advice. The 'show don't tell' technique is one of the most important writing concepts — point it out in other reading too.

title: Writing Dialogue — Quotation Marks and Dialogue Tags
description: Students learn to write dialogue using quotation marks, dialogue tags (said, asked, shouted), and proper punctuation. They practice writing conversations that reveal character personality and advance a story.
instructions:
1. Read a page of dialogue from the current read-aloud book.
2. Identify quotation marks, dialogue tags, and punctuation.
3. Teach the rules: quotation marks around spoken words, comma before the tag.
4. Practice: convert 'She said she was happy' to 'I am happy!' she said.
5. Use different dialogue tags to show emotion: whispered, shouted, asked, exclaimed.
6. Write a conversation between two characters.
7. Read dialogue aloud with expression.

slides.heading: Writing Dialogue
slides.subheading: Making Characters Speak on the Page

items: Current read-aloud book (Ramona Quimby) open to a dialogue-rich page
Dialogue tag reference list: said, asked, whispered, shouted, exclaimed, replied, muttered, cried, announced, wondered
slides.setup_instructions: Find a page in the read-aloud with clear dialogue formatting. Write 3 example dialogue sentences on the board or paper showing quotation marks, tags, and punctuation. Have the reference list of dialogue tags visible.

slides.text: When characters SPEAK in a story, their exact words go inside QUOTATION MARKS: "I love pizza!" said Marco. The quotation marks tell the reader: these are the actual words someone spoke. Everything OUTSIDE the quotation marks is the narrator's description.

The DIALOGUE TAG tells who is speaking and how. It usually comes after the spoken words: "Let's go!" she SHOUTED. Or before: He WHISPERED, "Follow me." Notice the punctuation: a COMMA separates the spoken words from the tag (inside the quotation marks). If the spoken words end with ! or ?, no comma is needed.

Different dialogue tags create different moods. Compare: "I'm not going," she SAID. (Neutral.) "I'm not going!" she SHOUTED. (Angry.) "I'm not going," she WHISPERED. (Scared or secretive.) "I'm not going," she SIGHED. (Tired or resigned.) The TAG changes everything!

When writing a conversation, start a NEW PARAGRAPH each time a different person speaks. This helps the reader follow who is talking:

"Are you ready?" asked Mom.
"Almost!" Ramona called from her room.
"We need to leave in five minutes," Mom said firmly.

slides.prompt: Write a conversation between TWO characters (real or made up) about a problem they need to solve. The conversation should be at least 8 lines of dialogue. Use quotation marks correctly. Use at least 4 different dialogue tags (not just 'said' every time). Start a new paragraph for each speaker. Make the characters sound different from each other — one might be excited while the other is worried.

slides.text: Dialogue brings characters to life! When you write a character's exact words, the reader can HEAR their voice. Good dialogue reveals personality, creates emotion, and moves the story forward. Notice dialogue in everything you read this week — books, comics, and even text messages are a form of written dialogue!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly punctuate dialogue with quotation marks and tags, use varied dialogue tags, and write a conversation between two distinct characters?

parent_notes: Dialogue writing is a major milestone in language development. The punctuation rules (quotation marks, comma placement, new paragraph per speaker) are complex but become automatic with practice. Focus on one rule at a time — quotation marks first, then commas, then paragraphing. Using the read-aloud book as a model is powerful: 'See how Beverly Cleary wrote this dialogue? Let us try it the same way.' Encourage your child to read their dialogue aloud — it should sound like real people talking. If every line sounds the same, help them differentiate character voices.

title: Multiplication Review — Mixed Facts and Patterns
description: Students review multiplication facts for 2s, 3s, 4s, 5s, 6s, and 10s through games, timed practice, and pattern discovery. They identify relationships between tables and build toward automaticity.
instructions:
1. Quick review of each table with skip counting.
2. Practice mixed flash cards (all tables).
3. Discover cross-table patterns: 3 x 4 = 12, 4 x 3 = 12 (commutative property).
4. Play multiplication war (card game).
5. Complete a partial multiplication chart.
6. Identify remaining 'hard facts' to focus on.
7. Timed challenge: how many facts in 2 minutes?

slides.heading: Multiplication Review
slides.subheading: Mastering All Learned Facts

items: Flash cards for 2s, 3s, 4s, 5s, 6s, and 10s mixed together
Deck of playing cards (face cards removed) for multiplication war
slides.setup_instructions: Mix all flash cards together. Prepare a 10x10 multiplication chart with some cells filled and others blank. Set up the card game: each player draws 2 cards and multiplies them; highest product wins the round.

slides.text: Let us see how well you know ALL your multiplication facts! Quick skip count: 2s to 20, 3s to 30, 4s to 40, 5s to 50, 6s to 60, 10s to 100. Good! Now the real test: can you answer MIXED facts quickly? 4 x 6? 3 x 8? 6 x 5? 2 x 9? The goal is AUTOMATIC — no counting, just knowing.

Important discovery: multiplication is COMMUTATIVE — 3 x 4 = 4 x 3 = 12. This means every fact you learn counts TWICE! If you know 6 x 3 = 18, you automatically know 3 x 6 = 18. The multiplication chart is symmetrical — one diagonal half mirrors the other!

Look at the multiplication chart. Fill in what you KNOW immediately. The facts you cannot fill in quickly are your 'focus facts' — the ones that need more practice. Common hard facts: 6 x 7, 6 x 8, 7 x 8, 8 x 6. We have not learned 7s, 8s, or 9s tables yet, but you already know some of them from the tables you HAVE learned!

slides.prompt: 1) Fill in the multiplication chart as fast as you can for the tables you know (2s, 3s, 4s, 5s, 6s, 10s). 2) Circle any facts you had to think hard about — those are your focus facts. 3) Play multiplication war: each player draws 2 cards and multiplies. Highest product wins. Play 10 rounds. 4) Timed challenge: how many flash cards can you answer correctly in 2 minutes? Record your score — beat it next time!

slides.text: You know MORE multiplication facts than you realize! Between 2s, 3s, 4s, 5s, 6s, and 10s (plus the commutative twins), you have covered most of the multiplication chart. The remaining tables (7s, 8s, 9s) are coming soon. Keep your focus facts list and practice those every day — even 2 minutes of practice builds automaticity!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child answer mixed multiplication facts from learned tables within 5 seconds and identify their personal 'focus facts'?

parent_notes: Multiplication fact fluency is built through short, frequent practice — not long drill sessions. The multiplication chart activity reveals what the child knows and what needs work. The 'focus facts' approach is targeted and efficient: practice the 5-10 facts that are not yet automatic rather than reviewing all 100. Card games make practice fun and social. The timed challenge should be framed as 'beat your own score' rather than competitive with others. Consider a daily 2-minute fact practice routine: flash cards while waiting for dinner, during car rides, or before bed.

title: Sound and Vibrations — How Sound Travels
description: Students discover that sound is caused by vibrations and travels through matter (solids, liquids, and gases). They conduct experiments with tuning forks, rubber bands, and drums to see, feel, and hear vibrations in action.
instructions:
1. Present the question: What IS sound?
2. Demonstrate: pluck a rubber band stretched over a box — see it vibrate AND hear the sound.
3. Introduce the concept: sound is caused by VIBRATIONS.
4. Touch a vibrating surface (drum, tuning fork) — feel the vibrations.
5. Experiment: sound travels through air (clap), solids (put ear to table), and water.
6. Discuss: sound cannot travel through a vacuum (space is silent!).
7. Record observations in science journal.

slides.heading: Sound and Vibrations
slides.subheading: What Is Sound and How Does It Travel?

items: Rubber bands of different sizes and thicknesses
Open box or tissue box (for rubber band guitar)
Drum, pot, or large bowl with plastic wrap stretched over top
Rice or salt grains (to visualize vibrations)
slides.setup_instructions: Set up three experiment stations. Station 1: rubber band guitar (bands stretched across open box). Station 2: drum with rice grains on top. Station 3: bowl of water for tuning fork vibration. Quiet environment is best for sound experiments.

slides.text: Sound is everywhere — voices, music, birds, traffic, wind. But what IS sound? Let us investigate! Stretch a rubber band across this box. Now PLUCK it. What do you see? The rubber band is moving back and forth very fast — it is VIBRATING! What do you hear? A sound! Sound is caused by VIBRATIONS.

Put rice grains on top of the drum (or plastic-wrapped bowl). Now HIT the drum. Watch the rice JUMP! The drum surface vibrates, and those vibrations move the rice. You can SEE the vibrations! Touch the drum gently right after hitting it — can you FEEL the vibrations tingling on your fingers?

Sound vibrations travel through the AIR as invisible waves — like ripples in a pond. These waves reach your ear, where tiny bones and membranes vibrate in response, and your brain interprets it as sound! Sound can also travel through SOLIDS (put your ear on the table and tap — louder!) and LIQUIDS (whales communicate through ocean water for miles!).

But sound CANNOT travel through empty space (a vacuum). In space, there is no air for vibrations to travel through, so space is completely SILENT! Explosions in space movies should be silent — but that would not be as exciting! Sound needs MATTER (solid, liquid, or gas) to travel.

slides.prompt: Experiment and record: 1) Rubber band guitar: pluck bands of different thicknesses. Which makes a higher sound? Which makes a lower sound? 2) Put your ear to the table while someone taps. Is the sound louder through the table or through the air? Why? 3) Touch a vibrating surface (drum, fork) — describe what you feel. Draw all three experiments with labels. Write: What causes sound? What does sound need to travel?

slides.text: Sound is vibrations traveling through matter! Every sound you hear — from a whisper to a thunderclap — is caused by something vibrating and those vibrations reaching your ears through air, water, or solid material. This week we will explore more: pitch, volume, and how musical instruments make different sounds!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain that sound is caused by vibrations, demonstrate vibrations, and describe how sound travels through solids, liquids, and gases?

parent_notes: Sound experiments are engaging and accessible. The rubber band guitar demonstrates the connection between vibration and sound perfectly. The rice-on-drum visualization makes invisible vibrations visible. Encourage the child to explore sounds throughout the house: what vibrates when a piano key is pressed? When you speak, what vibrates (vocal cords)? The table experiment (ear on table while tapping) dramatically shows that sound travels faster and louder through solids than air. If you have a tuning fork, dip it in water after striking — the vibrations create visible splashes.

title: Medieval Coat of Arms — Heraldic Design and Symbolism
description: Students deepen their understanding of medieval heraldry by studying the rules and symbols of coats of arms. They create a detailed family coat of arms following authentic heraldic rules including division patterns, charges, and color rules.
instructions:
1. Review the coat of arms from the knights lesson.
2. Introduce heraldic rules: the rule of tincture (no metal on metal, no color on color).
3. Explain division patterns: per pale (vertical), per fess (horizontal), quarterly (4 parts).
4. Present common charges (symbols): lion (courage), eagle (strength), cross (faith), oak (endurance).
5. The child designs a family coat of arms following authentic rules.
6. Add a motto (a short phrase of values).
7. Display the finished design.

slides.heading: Family Coat of Arms
slides.subheading: Designing with Heraldic Rules and Symbols

items: Heraldry reference chart showing colors, divisions, and charges
Colored pencils or markers: gold/yellow, silver/white, red, blue, green, black, purple
Pencil and ruler for division lines
slides.setup_instructions: Print a large shield template. Create a heraldry reference showing: tincture rules (metals: gold/silver; colors: red, blue, green, black, purple), division patterns, and common charges with their meanings.

slides.text: Heraldry has rules that are over 800 years old! The most important is the RULE OF TINCTURE: never place a color on a color or a metal on a metal. The 'metals' are GOLD (or yellow) and SILVER (or white). The 'colors' are red, blue, green, black, and purple. So a blue lion on a gold background is correct, but a blue lion on a red background breaks the rule!

Shields can be DIVIDED in patterns. PER PALE means split vertically into left and right halves (different colors). PER FESS means split horizontally into top and bottom. QUARTERLY means split into four sections. PER BEND means split diagonally. Each section can have its own charge (symbol).

CHARGES are the symbols on the shield. Each has meaning! LION = courage and royalty. EAGLE = strength and vision. CROSS = faith. OAK TREE = endurance. HORSE = speed and readiness. STARS = excellence. WAVES = the sea. SWORD = military honor. BOOK = learning. Choose symbols that represent YOUR family's values!

slides.prompt: Design your family's official coat of arms. Follow these steps: 1) Choose a shield division pattern. 2) Select 2-3 charges (symbols) that represent your family's values. 3) Color following the tincture rule (no color on color, no metal on metal). 4) Create a motto — a short phrase that captures your family's spirit (e.g., 'Ever Forward,' 'Strength in Kindness,' 'Learn and Grow'). Write it on a banner below the shield. Present your design to your family!

slides.text: Your family coat of arms represents WHO YOU ARE through symbols and colors that carry 800 years of tradition. In the Middle Ages, every noble family had one, and heralds could identify every knight on a battlefield by their shield. Your design carries forward this ancient tradition with YOUR family's unique identity!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child follow heraldic tincture rules, use appropriate division patterns and charges, and explain the symbolism of their design choices?

parent_notes: This expanded heraldry lesson goes deeper than the initial coat of arms activity. Following the actual rules of heraldry adds rigor and historical authenticity. The tincture rule ensures high contrast and visibility — a practical military consideration. If your child enjoys this, heraldry can become a research project: look up real coats of arms of countries, cities, or historical families. The family motto exercise is meaningful — deciding on a family phrase of values can become a lasting family tradition. Frame and display the finished coat of arms.

title: Cooking — Vegetable Soup from Scratch
description: Students prepare a hearty vegetable soup, learning to wash, peel, and chop vegetables safely. They follow a recipe that connects to medieval cooking (pottage was the main food of medieval peasants) and practice kitchen safety skills.
instructions:
1. Connect to history: medieval peasants ate pottage (thick vegetable stew) daily.
2. Read and discuss the recipe.
3. Wash all vegetables thoroughly.
4. Demonstrate safe knife skills: the claw grip and bridge cut.
5. Chop vegetables (with supervision).
6. Add to broth and simmer.
7. Season and taste.
8. Serve and eat together.
9. Clean up completely.
materials_needed: Vegetables (carrots, celery, potatoes, onion, green beans)

slides.heading: Vegetable Soup
slides.subheading: A Modern Version of Medieval Pottage

items: 2 carrots, 2 celery stalks, 2 potatoes, 1 onion, handful of green beans
Salt, pepper, dried thyme or oregano
Large pot, cutting board, safe knife, vegetable peeler
slides.setup_instructions: Gather and wash all vegetables before starting. An adult must supervise all knife work. Demonstrate the claw grip (fingers curled, knuckles forward) and bridge cut (bridge fingers over small round items) before the child cuts anything. Pre-chop the onion if the child cannot manage it.

slides.text: Medieval peasants ate POTTAGE almost every day — a thick soup of whatever vegetables and grains they had. It simmered over the fire all day, and people added to it throughout the week. Today we make our own version — a hearty vegetable soup that connects us to a cooking tradition that is over 1,000 years old!

KNIFE SAFETY is essential. Rule 1: The CLAW GRIP — curl your fingers so your knuckles guide the knife, not your fingertips. Rule 2: Always cut AWAY from your body. Rule 3: Use the BRIDGE CUT for round items — make a bridge with your thumb and finger, and cut through the center. Rule 4: A sharp knife is actually SAFER than a dull one because it slips less.

Let us cook! Heat olive oil in the pot. Add chopped onion and cook until soft (3 minutes). Add diced carrots, celery, and potatoes. Stir for 2 minutes. Add broth and bring to a boil. Reduce heat and simmer for 20 minutes until vegetables are tender. Add green beans for the last 5 minutes. Season with salt, pepper, and herbs.

slides.prompt: While the soup simmers, write the recipe in your recipe journal. Taste the soup before seasoning and after — notice how salt changes flavor! Write a comparison: How is our soup similar to medieval pottage? How is it different? (We have tomatoes, they did not!) Rate the soup and suggest one ingredient you would add next time. Clean up while you wait for the soup to finish!

slides.text: You cooked a meal from scratch — something humans have done for hundreds of thousands of years! Soup is one of the most versatile and forgiving recipes. You can add almost anything: beans, pasta, rice, different vegetables, different herbs. Medieval peasants would be amazed at our variety of ingredients, but the basic idea is exactly the same: put good things in a pot with water and make something nourishing.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child demonstrate safe knife techniques (claw grip and bridge cut), follow a multi-step recipe, and connect the meal to medieval food history?

parent_notes: Vegetable soup is an ideal recipe for developing knife skills because the cuts do not need to be perfect — everything cooks down! The claw grip is the single most important kitchen safety skill. Demonstrate it multiple times and supervise closely. The medieval pottage connection enriches the history curriculum. Let the child season the soup to their taste — this builds confidence and ownership. Soup is also perfect for discussing nutrition: vegetables provide vitamins, broth provides minerals and hydration. Consider making soup a regular family cooking activity.

title: Journal Writing — Writing from a Historical Perspective
description: Students write a journal entry from the perspective of a person living in the Middle Ages, using historical knowledge, dialogue, and descriptive language. They choose to write as a knight, monk, peasant, or cathedral builder.
instructions:
1. Review what we have learned about the Middle Ages.
2. Discuss historical perspective writing: imagining life through another person's eyes.
3. The child chooses a medieval character.
4. Brainstorm: What would this person see, hear, feel, eat, do in a day?
5. Write a first-person journal entry for one day.
6. Include sensory details, dialogue, and emotional responses.
7. Share and discuss.

slides.heading: Historical Perspective Writing
slides.subheading: A Day in the Middle Ages

items: History journal notes about the Middle Ages for reference
Images of medieval life for inspiration
slides.setup_instructions: Review the medieval topics covered: feudalism, castles, knights, monks, cathedrals, towns, guilds, daily life. Have the child's history journal available for reference. Encourage them to use specific historical details.

slides.text: Today you become a time traveler — through WRITING! You will write a journal entry as if you lived in the Middle Ages. This is called HISTORICAL PERSPECTIVE WRITING. You use everything you have learned about history to imagine what life felt like for a real person in that time.

Choose your character: A KNIGHT preparing for a tournament? A MONK in the scriptorium copying a manuscript? A PEASANT during harvest season? A CATHEDRAL BUILDER high on the scaffolding? A GUILD APPRENTICE learning a craft? Each person would experience the medieval world differently.

Include SENSORY DETAILS from the time period. What do you see? (Stone walls, flickering torches, crowded markets.) What do you hear? (Church bells, hammer on anvil, roosters.) What do you smell? (Baking bread, horse dung, incense.) What do you eat? (Pottage, bread, no potatoes!) What do you FEEL — emotions and physical sensations?

Use the skills we have practiced: ADJECTIVES for vivid description, ADVERBS for precise actions, COMPOUND SENTENCES for smooth flow, DIALOGUE for conversations with other medieval people. Remember to write in FIRST PERSON: 'I woke before dawn...'

slides.prompt: Write a journal entry of at least 2 paragraphs from your medieval character's perspective. Describe one full day from waking to sleeping. Include: at least 5 historical details from our lessons, sensory descriptions (at least 3 senses), 2 lines of dialogue with another character, 2 compound sentences, and your character's feelings about their life. This is YOUR masterpiece of historical imagination!

slides.text: Historical perspective writing is one of the most powerful ways to understand history. When you IMAGINE being a person from another time, you move beyond facts and dates to understanding how people actually LIVED and FELT. Historians call this historical empathy — and it is what makes history come alive.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child write a historically accurate first-person account using sensory details, dialogue, and specific historical knowledge from lessons?

parent_notes: This lesson is the culmination of weeks of medieval history study. The child draws on everything they have learned to create an imaginative but historically grounded narrative. Historical perspective writing develops empathy, research skills, and creative writing simultaneously. Encourage accuracy — if the child writes about a peasant eating chocolate, gently remind them that chocolate came from the Americas and was not available in medieval Europe! The exercise should feel like play, not an assignment. Some children write pages when given permission to imagine freely.

title: Measurement — Measuring in Feet and Yards
description: Students extend their measurement skills to larger units: feet (12 inches) and yards (3 feet). They use yardsticks and tape measures to measure room dimensions, furniture, and their own height, and convert between inches, feet, and yards.
instructions:
1. Review inches and centimeters.
2. Introduce the foot: 12 inches = 1 foot. Measure items about 1 foot long.
3. Introduce the yard: 3 feet = 1 yard (about the distance from nose to fingertip).
4. Practice with a yardstick and tape measure.
5. Measure room dimensions, furniture height, and personal height.
6. Convert: How many inches in 2 feet? How many feet in 2 yards?
7. Record all measurements.
materials_needed: Various objects and spaces to measure

slides.heading: Feet and Yards
slides.subheading: Measuring Bigger Things

items: Yardstick or tape measure (at least 10 feet)
Objects and spaces to measure: doorway height, table length, room width, child's height
slides.setup_instructions: Have both a ruler and yardstick/tape measure ready. Identify several things to measure that are bigger than 12 inches. Prepare conversion practice problems.

slides.text: Inches are great for small things, but imagine measuring your room in inches — you would need hundreds! For bigger measurements, we use FEET and YARDS. 1 FOOT = 12 INCHES. That is about the length of a large adult foot (which is where the name comes from!). 1 YARD = 3 FEET = 36 INCHES. A yard is about the distance from your nose to your outstretched fingertip.

Benchmarks for feet: a ruler is 1 foot. A standard piece of paper is just under 1 foot long. A large watermelon is about 1 foot. For yards: the width of a door is about 1 yard. A guitar is about 1 yard long. A baseball bat is about 1 yard.

Let us measure BIG things! The doorway is about... 7 feet tall! The table is about... 3 feet wide (that is 1 yard!). YOUR height: stand against the wall, mark the top of your head, and measure. You are about... 4 feet 2 inches! We write: 4 ft 2 in or 4'2".

CONVERTING between units: How many inches in 3 feet? 3 x 12 = 36 inches. How many feet in 2 yards? 2 x 3 = 6 feet. How many inches in 2 yards? 2 x 36 = 72 inches! Always multiply to go from bigger units to smaller units.

slides.prompt: Measure and record: 1) Your height in feet and inches. 2) The width of a doorway. 3) The length of the room. 4) The height of a table. 5) The length of your bed. Write each in feet and inches. Then convert: 6) How many inches is your height? 7) How many feet is the room length? 8) If you walked 10 yards, how many feet is that? Draw a diagram of your room with measurements labeled.

slides.text: Now you can measure anything — from a paper clip (inches) to a room (feet and yards)! Inches for small things, feet for medium things, yards for big things. Builders, architects, and carpenters use these measurements every day. Your height will be measured in feet and inches for your whole life — now you know exactly what those numbers mean!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child measure objects in feet and inches using a tape measure and convert between inches, feet, and yards?

parent_notes: Extending measurement to feet and yards makes the skill practical for real-world applications. Measuring their own height is always a hit — consider marking heights on a growth chart. The conversion between units (12 inches per foot, 3 feet per yard) involves multiplication, reinforcing math facts naturally. For the metric system, the equivalent larger units (meters and kilometers) will come later. Make measurement a habit: when you buy furniture, ask the child to help measure the space. When cooking, have them measure ingredients. When gardening, measure the garden plot.

title: Medieval Castles — Siege Warfare and Defense
description: Students learn about medieval siege warfare: how armies attacked castles and how castles were designed to resist. They study siege weapons (trebuchets, battering rams, siege towers) and defensive features (murder holes, boiling oil, portcullises).
instructions:
1. Review castle defensive features from week 17.
2. Explain siege warfare: when an army surrounds a castle to force surrender.
3. Describe siege weapons: trebuchet, battering ram, siege tower, catapult.
4. Describe castle defenses: murder holes, portcullis, arrow loops, hot oil.
5. Discuss the siege dilemma: attackers could wait months; defenders could starve.
6. The child designs siege weapons or defensive improvements.
7. Record in history journal.
materials_needed: Images of siege weapons and castle defenses

slides.heading: Castle Sieges
slides.subheading: Attack and Defense in Medieval Warfare

items: Images of trebuchets, battering rams, siege towers, and castle defensive features
Drawing materials for siege weapon or defense design
slides.setup_instructions: Display images of siege weapons alongside castle defensive features. If possible, show a diagram of a siege in progress. Have drawing materials ready for the design activity.

slides.text: Castles were built to be almost impossible to capture. But armies kept inventing new ways to attack! This back-and-forth between attack and defense drove castle design for 500 years. When someone invented a better weapon, castle builders invented a better defense. Let us explore both sides.

SIEGE WEAPONS — to attack castles: The TREBUCHET was a giant catapult that could hurl 300-pound stones over castle walls (the most powerful siege weapon!). The BATTERING RAM was a huge log swung at gates. SIEGE TOWERS were rolling wooden towers as tall as the walls — soldiers climbed inside and crossed to the walls on top. CATAPULTS launched smaller stones and even disease-ridden material (an early form of biological warfare!).

CASTLE DEFENSES — to resist siege: MURDER HOLES were openings above the gate passage where defenders dropped boiling water or rocks on attackers entering below. The PORTCULLIS was a heavy iron gate that dropped to block entry. MACHICOLATIONS were stone platforms that jutted out from walls, allowing defenders to drop things on attackers at the base. CONCENTRIC CASTLES had walls within walls — if attackers breached the outer wall, they faced another wall inside!

The biggest threat in a siege was not weapons but TIME. Armies would surround the castle and WAIT. If they cut off food supplies, the castle would eventually starve. Some sieges lasted MONTHS or even years! Castle builders responded by digging deep wells, stockpiling food, and building secret escape tunnels. The longest siege in history lasted 3 years!

slides.prompt: In your history journal, draw and label at least 3 siege weapons AND 3 castle defensive features. Then choose one side: Are you the ATTACKER or DEFENDER? Design either a new siege weapon or a new castle defense improvement. Draw your invention, label its parts, and explain how it works. Write a paragraph describing a siege from your perspective (attacker or defender).

slides.text: Medieval siege warfare shows the endless cycle of invention: every new attack created a new defense, and every defense inspired a new attack. This pattern continues today in many fields — technology, sports, business. Understanding this cycle helps us see that problems always lead to solutions, which lead to new problems. That is how human ingenuity works!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name 3 siege weapons and 3 defensive features and explain the siege strategy of starving a castle?

parent_notes: Siege warfare is dramatic and engaging, especially for children who enjoy strategy and engineering. The trebuchet in particular captures children's imagination — there are many YouTube videos showing working reconstructions. If your child enjoys this topic, building a small trebuchet from popsicle sticks is an excellent STEM project. The attack-defense cycle is a powerful thinking framework that applies to many areas of life. Balance the military content with the human cost — sieges were devastating for civilians inside castles, especially peasants who had taken refuge.

title: Climate Zones — How Climate Affects Plant and Animal Life
description: Students explore how climate zones determine which plants and animals can survive in different regions, creating distinct biomes. They study tropical rainforests, temperate forests, and tundra as examples of climate-biome connections.
instructions:
1. Review the three climate zones from Day 1.
2. Introduce biomes: large regions defined by climate and living things.
3. Tropical biome: dense vegetation, incredible biodiversity.
4. Temperate biome: deciduous forests, grasslands, moderate diversity.
5. Polar biome: tundra, few species but highly adapted.
6. Connect: why do polar bears not live in tropical forests?
7. The child creates a biome comparison chart.
8. Record in geography journal.
materials_needed: Images of tropical, temperate, and polar biomes

slides.heading: Climate and Biomes
slides.subheading: How Climate Shapes Life on Earth

items: Images of tropical rainforests, temperate forests, and arctic tundra
slides.setup_instructions: Display the biome map alongside the climate zone map from Day 1. Gather dramatic images of each biome showing characteristic plants and animals.

slides.text: Climate zones do not just determine weather — they determine WHAT CAN LIVE THERE! A BIOME is a large region with specific climate, plants, and animals that have adapted to those conditions. Tropical climates create rainforest biomes. Temperate climates create forest and grassland biomes. Polar climates create tundra biomes.

TROPICAL BIOMES (near equator): Hot and wet year-round. Result: the most diverse life on Earth! Rainforests have layers of plants from giant trees to tiny mosses. Animals: monkeys, toucans, jaguars, tree frogs, millions of insects. Over HALF of all species on Earth live in tropical biomes!

TEMPERATE BIOMES (middle latitudes): Four seasons with moderate temperatures. DECIDUOUS forests have trees that lose leaves in fall (oak, maple, beech). Animals: deer, bears, foxes, squirrels, songbirds. These forests change dramatically through the seasons — green in summer, golden in fall, bare in winter, budding in spring.

POLAR BIOMES (near poles): Extremely cold, with frozen ground (permafrost). The TUNDRA has no trees — only low shrubs, mosses, and lichens that survive the harsh conditions. Animals: polar bears, arctic foxes, caribou, snowy owls. Every species here has special adaptations: thick fur, fat layers, color changes for camouflage.

slides.prompt: Create a biome comparison chart with three columns: Tropical, Temperate, and Polar. For each biome, include: climate description, 3 plants, 3 animals, a description of the landscape, and a small illustration. Then answer: Why cannot a polar bear survive in a tropical rainforest? Why cannot a toucan survive in the tundra? Write at least 3 sentences explaining how animals are adapted to their climate zones.

slides.text: Climate shapes EVERYTHING about life in a region — from the tallest trees to the smallest insects. Organisms evolve to fit their climate over thousands of years, which is why each biome has unique species found nowhere else. Protecting biomes means protecting the incredible diversity of life that climate has created!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child connect climate zones to biomes, name characteristic plants and animals of each, and explain why organisms are adapted to specific climates?

parent_notes: The climate-biome connection is one of the most important ecological concepts. Children who understand this relationship see the natural world differently — they understand WHY different places have different life forms. The adaptation discussion (why polar bears have thick fur, why tropical plants have huge leaves) builds scientific thinking. If your child is interested in a particular biome, encourage independent research — biome studies are rich projects that integrate geography, science, art, and writing. Consider creating a biome diorama in a shoebox for a hands-on extension.

title: Read Aloud — The Cricket in Times Square, Chapters 1-4
description: Begin George Selden's 'The Cricket in Times Square,' a story about Chester the cricket who arrives in New York City from Connecticut. Students discuss setting, friendship between unlikely characters, and the magic of an unfamiliar place.
instructions:
1. Introduce the book and author George Selden.
2. Read chapters 1-4 aloud.
3. Discuss the setting: Times Square subway station in 1960s New York.
4. Meet the characters: Chester Cricket, Tucker Mouse, Harry Cat, Mario.
5. Discuss: How does Chester feel in a strange new place?
6. Compare this to Ramona's feelings about new situations.
7. The child draws the newsstand setting and writes about the characters.
materials_needed: The Cricket in Times Square by George Selden

slides.heading: The Cricket in Times Square
slides.subheading: Chapters 1-4: A Cricket in New York City

items: The Cricket in Times Square by George Selden
slides.setup_instructions: This book has a completely different tone from Ramona — it is whimsical and gentle, featuring talking animals in a realistic setting. Read with warmth. Use different voices: Chester is earnest, Tucker is fast-talking and enthusiastic, Harry is calm and wise.

slides.text: We are starting a very different kind of story! 'The Cricket in Times Square' is about Chester, a cricket from the quiet countryside of Connecticut, who accidentally ends up in the busiest place in the world: the Times Square subway station in New York City! He makes friends with Tucker Mouse and Harry Cat.

Notice the SETTING — George Selden describes Times Square in amazing detail: the noise, the crowds, the neon lights, the rumble of subway trains. For Chester, coming from a peaceful meadow, this is overwhelming! Think about a time YOU were somewhere completely new and different. How did it feel?

The friendships in this book are between very UNLIKELY characters: a cricket, a mouse, and a cat! In real life, a cat would eat both a cricket and a mouse. But in this story, friendship crosses boundaries. Pay attention to how Tucker and Harry welcome Chester — what do good friends do when someone is new and scared?

slides.prompt: In your reading journal, draw Mario's newsstand in the subway station (use details from the book!). Create character cards for Chester, Tucker, and Harry: name, animal, personality traits (at least 3 each), and what they think about Times Square. Write a prediction: How will Chester's musical talent change his life? What adventures will he have?

slides.text: The Cricket in Times Square is about finding home in unexpected places and friendship between creatures who are very different from each other. Chester has a special gift — his musical chirping. Great stories often feature characters who have unique talents that change their world. Let us find out what happens when Chester's music meets New York City!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child describe the setting and main characters, identify the theme of friendship between unlikely characters, and make predictions?

parent_notes: The Cricket in Times Square is a gentle, charming book that appeals to children who love animals, music, and friendship stories. The 1960s New York City setting is historical for today's children, offering opportunities to discuss how cities have changed. Tucker Mouse is a scene-stealer — his fast-talking personality is fun to voice. The theme of finding beauty (Chester's music) in an overwhelming urban setting resonates with many children. If your child loved James and the Giant Peach but is less engaged by realistic fiction, this book bridges the gap with its talking animals in a real setting.

title: Spelling and Vocabulary — Latin and Greek Roots
description: Students are introduced to the concept that many English words come from Latin and Greek roots. They learn common roots (aud = hear, vis = see, port = carry, graph = write) and discover how knowing roots helps decode unfamiliar words.
instructions:
1. Discuss: English borrows words from many languages, especially Latin and Greek.
2. Present root 'aud' (hear): audience, audio, auditorium.
3. Present root 'vis/vid' (see): visible, video, vision.
4. Present root 'port' (carry): transport, portable, export.
5. Present root 'graph' (write): autograph, biography, photograph.
6. The child builds word families from each root.
7. Try to decode unfamiliar words using root knowledge.

slides.heading: Latin and Greek Roots
slides.subheading: The Building Blocks of English Words

items: Root word cards: aud (hear), vis/vid (see), port (carry), graph/gram (write)
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare root cards with the root, meaning, and 3-4 example words. Create a word family chart for each root. Have a dictionary available for exploring additional words.

slides.text: Here is a SUPERPOWER for reading and spelling: many English words are built from ROOTS — word parts that came from Latin and Greek thousands of years ago. If you know the root, you can figure out the meaning of words you have NEVER seen before! Let us learn four powerful roots today.

Root AUD means HEAR (from Latin). AUDIENCE: people who come to HEAR. AUDIO: related to HEARING (audio book = a book you HEAR). AUDITORIUM: a place for HEARING (concerts, speeches). AUDIBLE: able to be HEARD. If you see 'aud' in a word, it is about hearing!

Root VIS/VID means SEE (from Latin). VISIBLE: able to be SEEN. VISION: the ability to SEE. VIDEO: something you SEE (recorded images). INVISIBLE: NOT able to be seen (in + visible). Root PORT means CARRY (from Latin). TRANSPORT: CARRY across. PORTABLE: able to be CARRIED. EXPORT: CARRY out of a country.

Root GRAPH means WRITE (from Greek). AUTOGRAPH: writing by oneself (auto = self). BIOGRAPHY: writing about a life (bio = life). PHOTOGRAPH: writing with light (photo = light). GEOGRAPHY: writing about the earth (geo = earth)! Even our school subject names use Greek roots!

slides.prompt: Create a word family chart for each root. For AUD, VIS, PORT, and GRAPH, list at least 3 words containing that root and explain how the root's meaning connects to the word's meaning. Then try to decode these words using root knowledge: 'inaudible' (in + aud + ible), 'television' (tele + vis + ion), 'import' (im + port). Write a sentence for each root using one of its words.

slides.text: Knowing Latin and Greek roots is like having a SECRET DECODER for English! Over 60% of English words have Latin or Greek roots. When you encounter an unfamiliar word, look for a root you recognize — it will often give you enough meaning to understand the word. We will learn more roots throughout the year. You are becoming a word detective!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child define 4 Latin/Greek roots, give examples of words containing each, and use root knowledge to decode an unfamiliar word?

parent_notes: Latin and Greek roots are one of the most powerful vocabulary-building tools available. Research shows that teaching roots dramatically improves reading comprehension because children can decode unfamiliar words independently. Start with these four roots and add more gradually (tele = far, bio = life, auto = self, phon = sound, aqua = water). Make it a game: when you encounter a new word, challenge the child to find its root. This skill pays dividends for years — SAT vocabulary, science terminology, and legal/medical terms all rely on Latin and Greek roots.

title: Quarter 2 Math Review — Operations and Fractions
description: Students review all major math concepts from Quarter 2: multi-digit subtraction with borrowing, multiplication facts, introduction to division, fractions, and measurement. They complete a comprehensive practice set and identify areas needing more work.
instructions:
1. Warm up with skip counting: 3s, 4s, 6s.
2. Review subtraction with borrowing (2 problems).
3. Review multiplication and division facts (mixed flash cards).
4. Review fractions: compare, add, subtract with circles.
5. Review measurement: measure 2 objects in inches and centimeters.
6. Complete a comprehensive practice set.
7. Identify areas of strength and areas to improve.
8. Create a study plan for challenging topics.

slides.heading: Quarter 2 Math Review
slides.subheading: Celebrating How Much You Have Learned!

items: Mixed multiplication and division flash cards
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a mixed practice set covering all Q2 topics: 2 subtraction with borrowing, 5 multiplication, 3 division, 3 fraction problems, and 2 measurement tasks. Have fraction circles and ruler available. This is a review, not a test — the goal is to identify strengths and areas for growth.

slides.text: Let us celebrate everything you have learned in Quarter 2! You have mastered so many skills: subtraction with borrowing (even 3-digit!), multiplication facts (3s, 4s, 6s), introduction to division, fractions (comparing, adding, subtracting), and measurement (inches, centimeters, feet, yards). That is incredible progress!

Today we review each topic. For each problem, try your best. If something feels easy, that is a STRENGTH — celebrate it! If something feels hard, that is an area for GROWTH — we will work on it more. There are no grades, just useful information about where you are.

Tips for the review: Subtraction — line up your columns and work right to left. Multiplication — use strategies (doubling for 4s, 5+1 for 6s). Division — think multiplication! Fractions — use the circles if you need them. Measurement — start at zero on the ruler.

slides.prompt: Complete the review set: 1) 534 - 278, 2) 403 - 167, 3) 6 x 8, 4) 4 x 9, 5) 3 x 7, 6) 24 ÷ 6, 7) 36 ÷ 4, 8) 21 ÷ 3, 9) Compare: 2/3 ___ 3/4, 10) 2/5 + 1/5, 11) 5/6 - 2/6, 12) Measure your pencil in inches AND centimeters. After finishing, mark each problem: star for 'I got this!' and circle for 'I need more practice.' Count your stars — that is your strength score!

slides.text: Look at how much you know! At the beginning of the quarter, you could not borrow in subtraction, did not know the 3s table, had never divided, and had not worked with fractions. Now you can do ALL of those things! Every challenge you identified is something we will strengthen in Quarter 3. Learning is a journey, and you are making amazing progress.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child demonstrate competence in at least 4 of 5 Q2 math topics (subtraction, multiplication, division, fractions, measurement)?

parent_notes: End-of-quarter reviews help both child and parent see the big picture of progress. Frame this as a celebration, not a test. Emphasize strengths: 'You got 10 out of 12! Look how much you know!' For areas needing work, be specific and reassuring: 'Division with remainders needs a bit more practice — we will keep working on it.' Use the results to plan Q3 practice: if fractions are strong, maintain them; if subtraction borrowing is shaky, build in more practice. The visual record (stars vs. circles) makes progress tangible and motivating.

title: Sound — Pitch and Volume
description: Students explore how pitch (high/low) and volume (loud/soft) are created. They discover that pitch depends on vibration speed (frequency) and volume depends on vibration size (amplitude), using instruments and experiments to demonstrate.
instructions:
1. Review: sound is caused by vibrations.
2. Introduce PITCH: how high or low a sound is.
3. Demonstrate: shorter/thinner objects vibrate faster = higher pitch.
4. Rubber band guitar: compare thin and thick bands.
5. Water bottle xylophone: more water = lower pitch.
6. Introduce VOLUME: how loud or soft a sound is.
7. Demonstrate: bigger vibrations = louder sound (hit drum hard vs. soft).
8. Record observations.
materials_needed: Water bottles (5-6, filled to different levels)

slides.heading: Pitch and Volume
slides.subheading: The High and Low, Loud and Soft of Sound

items: Rubber band guitar with bands of different thicknesses
5-6 identical glass bottles filled with different amounts of water
Wooden mallet, spoon, or stick for tapping bottles
Drum or pot for volume experiments
slides.setup_instructions: Fill bottles with increasing amounts of water (empty, 1/4, 1/2, 3/4, full). Line them up. Have the rubber band guitar from the vibration lesson. Clear space on a table for the ruler experiment.

slides.text: All sounds have two main qualities: PITCH (how high or low) and VOLUME (how loud or soft). A bird chirping is high pitch. A drum booming is low pitch. A whisper is low volume. A shout is high volume. Today we discover what CAUSES these differences — and it all comes back to vibrations!

PITCH depends on how FAST something vibrates (called FREQUENCY). Fast vibrations = high pitch. Slow vibrations = low pitch. Experiment: extend a ruler off the edge of the table. Twang the short end (just 3 inches sticking out): HIGH pitch! Fast vibrations! Twang a long end (10 inches out): LOW pitch! Slow vibrations!

The water bottle xylophone shows the same thing! Tap each bottle. The one with the MOST water makes a LOW sound (more water vibrates slowly). The EMPTY bottle makes a HIGH sound (less water, air vibrates fast). You can tune the bottles by adding or removing water to play a scale!

VOLUME depends on how BIG the vibrations are (called AMPLITUDE). Hit the drum gently: soft sound, small vibrations. Hit it HARD: loud sound, BIG vibrations. Same pitch, different volume! You can feel the difference: touch the drum after a gentle tap vs. a hard hit. The hard hit vibrations are much stronger.

slides.prompt: Conduct three experiments and record results: 1) Ruler twang: measure how much ruler extends off the table for high, medium, and low pitch. 2) Water bottles: tap each bottle and rank from lowest to highest pitch. Draw the water levels. 3) Drum volume: tap gently, medium, and hard. Describe the volume and vibration size for each. Create a chart: 'Fast vibrations = ___ pitch' and 'Big vibrations = ___ volume.'

slides.text: Now you understand the science behind every sound: pitch comes from vibration SPEED (frequency), and volume comes from vibration SIZE (amplitude). This is how musical instruments work — a violin player changes pitch by pressing strings at different lengths, and changes volume by bowing harder or softer. Sound is beautiful physics!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain the relationship between vibration speed and pitch, vibration size and volume, and demonstrate both concepts experimentally?

parent_notes: The ruler experiment is particularly effective because children can see the vibrations, hear the pitch change, and control the variable (how much ruler extends). The water bottle xylophone can become a real musical instrument — with patience, you can tune it to play a simple scale. Volume and amplitude are often confused by adults and children alike — emphasize that volume is about the SIZE of vibrations, not the speed. Connect to the recorder: covering more holes (longer air column) makes lower pitch. Blowing harder makes louder, not higher!

title: Making Musical Instruments — Sound Science Meets Art
description: Students design and build simple musical instruments using household materials, applying their knowledge of pitch and volume from science class. They create at least two instruments and compose a short piece to perform.
instructions:
1. Review how pitch and volume work.
2. Present instrument categories: strings, percussion, wind.
3. Design instrument 1: a string instrument (rubber band guitar or shoebox harp).
4. Design instrument 2: a percussion instrument (shaker, drum, water xylophone).
5. Optional instrument 3: a wind instrument (straw oboe or bottle whistle).
6. Test and tune each instrument.
7. Compose a short piece using the instruments.
8. Perform!

slides.heading: Homemade Instruments
slides.subheading: Where Sound Science Meets Musical Creativity

items: Rubber bands of various sizes, open box (string instrument)
Plastic containers with lids, rice/beans/beads (percussion shaker)
5-6 water bottles at different levels (water xylophone)
Tape, cardboard tubes, and other craft supplies
slides.setup_instructions: Set up three instrument-building stations with materials organized. Have completed examples if possible. Test each instrument design in advance to ensure they work. Cover workspace for messy activities.

slides.text: You learned that sound comes from vibrations, pitch from vibration speed, and volume from vibration size. Now let us BUILD instruments that demonstrate these principles! There are three families of instruments: STRINGS (vibrating strings), PERCUSSION (vibrating surfaces or objects), and WIND (vibrating air).

STRING INSTRUMENT: Stretch rubber bands of different thicknesses across an open box. Thicker bands vibrate slower (lower pitch), thinner bands vibrate faster (higher pitch). Pluck them to play! You can also change pitch by pressing down on a band to shorten the vibrating length.

PERCUSSION INSTRUMENT: Fill a small container with rice or beans and seal it — shake for sound! More filling = different sound. Or use the water bottle xylophone from science. WIND INSTRUMENT: Flatten one end of a straw and cut it into a V-shape. Blow through the V — the straw vibrates and makes a buzzing sound! Cut the straw shorter for higher pitch.

slides.prompt: Build at least 2 instruments from different families. Test each one: Can you change the PITCH (higher and lower)? Can you change the VOLUME (louder and softer)? Label the science on each instrument in your music journal. Then compose a short piece using your instruments — at least 8 beats with a rhythm pattern. Name your composition and perform it!

slides.text: You are now both a scientist and a musician! Every instrument ever invented — from a prehistoric bone flute to a modern synthesizer — works on the same principles: vibrations creating sound waves. When you understand the science, you can create music from ANYTHING. Some of the world's greatest music has been made on simple, handmade instruments!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child build instruments from at least 2 families, explain the science behind how they produce different pitches and volumes, and perform a short composition?

parent_notes: This lesson brilliantly connects science and music. The instrument-building is engaging for all learning styles: kinesthetic (building), auditory (testing sounds), visual (seeing vibrations). The straw oboe can be tricky — the key is cutting a clean V-shape and applying steady, gentle air pressure. Not every instrument will sound beautiful, and that is fine — the learning is in the building and testing. If the child is particularly creative, this can become an extended project: building a full set of instruments and forming a 'one-person band.' Celebrate the composition by recording it on a phone!

title: Plant Care Update and Herb Harvest
description: Students check on their herb garden planted in week 16, measuring growth, recording observations, and harvesting any herbs that are ready. They learn about sustainable harvesting and use fresh herbs in a simple recipe.
instructions:
1. Visit the herb garden.
2. Measure plant height with a ruler.
3. Observe: leaf count, color, health.
4. Discuss what the plants needed and got (or did not get).
5. If herbs are ready, demonstrate how to harvest: cut just above a leaf node.
6. Use fresh herbs in a simple recipe (herb butter or herb water).
7. Plan continued care.
8. Update the plant observation journal.

slides.heading: Herb Garden Update
slides.subheading: Measuring Growth and First Harvest

items: Plant observation journal or science journal
Softened butter, small bowl, bread for herb butter
Pencil and colored pencils for drawings
slides.setup_instructions: Bring the herb garden to the work area. Have measuring tools ready. If herbs have not sprouted or have died, prepare to discuss what went wrong and replant. If herbs are thriving, prepare herb butter ingredients.

slides.text: It has been about 2 weeks since we planted our herbs! Let us check on them like scientists. First, OBSERVE: Are the plants alive? What color are the leaves? Are there new leaves since last time? Any problems — yellow leaves, drooping, insects? Write down everything you notice.

Now MEASURE: How tall is each plant from the soil to the top? Record the measurement in your journal. Compare to your last measurement. How much has each plant grown? If different herbs grew at different rates, why might that be? Some herbs grow faster than others — basil is speedy, parsley is slow!

If your herbs are big enough (at least 3-4 inches with multiple leaves), we can HARVEST some! The rule: never take more than one-third of the plant at once. Cut just ABOVE a set of leaves (a leaf node) — this encourages the plant to branch out and grow more. After harvesting, the plant will grow back even bushier!

Let us make HERB BUTTER! Chop your harvested herbs finely. Mix into softened butter with a pinch of salt. Spread on bread and taste. YOU grew this herb from a tiny seed! The journey from seed to plate is complete. This is the most Montessori moment of all — taking responsibility for growing your own food.

slides.prompt: Update your plant observation journal: date, height measurement, leaf count, overall health (scale of 1-5), and any problems noticed. Draw each plant as it looks today. If you harvested, write which herbs you picked and how much. Make herb butter and taste it. Write a comparison: How does fresh herb taste compared to dried herbs from a jar? Rate your gardening success and write one thing you would do differently next time.

slides.text: You grew food from seeds with your own care and attention! This is one of the most fundamental human skills — growing plants to eat. Every civilization in history depended on people who understood how to care for plants. Your herb garden is small, but the knowledge you gained is the same knowledge farmers use to feed the world.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child measure plant growth, record observations scientifically, harvest herbs properly, and reflect on the growing process?

parent_notes: This follow-up to the planting lesson completes the growing cycle. If the herbs died or failed to sprout, treat it as a learning experience — what went wrong? Too much water? Not enough light? Wrong temperature? Gardening failure is excellent science: forming hypotheses about what happened builds scientific thinking. If the herbs are thriving, the herb butter activity creates a memorable seed-to-table experience. Continue the observation journal weekly — tracking growth over time is real science. Consider expanding the garden with additional herbs or vegetables.

title: Quarter 2 Language Review — Writing Portfolio
description: Students review their best writing from Quarter 2 and select pieces for a writing portfolio. They reflect on their growth as writers, identify their strongest skills, and set goals for Quarter 3.
instructions:
1. Gather all writing from Quarter 2 (journal entries, narratives, poems, reports).
2. Read through each piece — notice improvement over time.
3. Select 3-4 best pieces for the portfolio.
4. Write a brief reflection for each piece: why you chose it, what it shows about your writing.
5. Identify: What is your strongest writing skill? What do you want to improve?
6. Set 2-3 writing goals for Quarter 3.
7. Compile the portfolio.

slides.heading: Writing Portfolio
slides.subheading: Celebrating Your Growth as a Writer

items: All Quarter 2 writing samples from the language journal
Reflection template (Title, Why I Chose This, What It Shows)
slides.setup_instructions: Gather all writing from Q2: descriptive paragraphs, spelling work, poems, personal narratives, book reports, dialogue exercises, historical perspective writing. Arrange them chronologically so the child can see growth over time. Prepare a portfolio folder.

slides.text: Writers keep PORTFOLIOS — collections of their best work that show growth and skill. Today you become the editor of your own portfolio! Look through everything you wrote in Quarter 2. You will choose your 3-4 BEST pieces — the ones that make you the most proud.

As you read through your writing, notice HOW MUCH YOU HAVE IMPROVED! Compare your first piece to your most recent. You probably see: more adjectives and adverbs, compound sentences, better spelling, dialogue, and stronger descriptions. THAT is growth, and you should be proud of every step.

For each piece you select, write a short REFLECTION: the title, why you chose it (What makes it your best work?), and what skill it demonstrates (descriptive writing, dialogue, poetry, historical perspective, etc.). This reflection shows that you understand your own writing strengths.

Finally, set GOALS for Quarter 3. What do you want to get better at? Maybe: 'I want to write longer stories' or 'I want to use more dialogue' or 'I want to spell more words correctly without help.' Good goals are specific and achievable. Write 2-3 goals for the next quarter.

slides.prompt: Review all your Q2 writing. Select your 3-4 best pieces. For each, write a reflection card: Title, Why I Chose It, and What Skill It Shows. Arrange them in your portfolio folder. Then write a 'Writer's Self-Assessment': What is your strongest writing skill? What improved the most this quarter? What are your 2-3 goals for Q3? Decorate your portfolio cover with your name and 'Quarter 2 Writing Portfolio.'

slides.text: Your writing portfolio is a record of your growth and achievement. Every professional writer started exactly where you are — learning the basics, practicing, and getting better with each piece. Look at this portfolio whenever you feel stuck or discouraged. It PROVES that you are improving. Quarter 3 is going to be amazing!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child select their best writing, articulate why each piece is strong, identify areas of growth, and set specific writing goals?

parent_notes: The writing portfolio is a powerful tool for building confidence and self-awareness. Children often do not realize how much they have improved until they compare early and late work. The reflection process develops metacognition — thinking about one's own learning. Display the portfolio or share it with grandparents or other family members to validate the child's work.
