The goal-setting exercise teaches children to take ownership of their learning. Revisit these goals at the start of Q3 and periodically throughout. This is a Montessori approach: the child assesses their own progress rather than being externally graded.

title: Measurement — Area Introduction with Square Units
description: Students are introduced to area as the amount of space inside a flat shape. They cover rectangles with square tiles to count the area in square units and discover the formula: area = length x width.
instructions:
1. Distinguish perimeter (distance around) from area (space inside).
2. Present a rectangle and fill it with square tiles.
3. Count the tiles: that number is the AREA in square units.
4. Notice: counting tiles is the same as multiplying rows by columns.
5. Introduce the formula: Area = length x width.
6. Practice with various rectangles.
7. Connect area to multiplication arrays.

slides.heading: Introduction to Area
slides.subheading: How Much Space Is Inside a Shape?

items: Square tiles (at least 50, all the same size — 1 inch or 1 cm)
Various paper rectangles of different sizes
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare rectangles on paper: 3x4, 5x2, 4x4, 6x3. Have plenty of square tiles. Graph paper helps visualize the grid pattern. Compare a perimeter example to an area example to establish the difference.

slides.text: We learned PERIMETER: the distance AROUND a shape. Today we learn AREA: the space INSIDE a shape. Imagine painting a wall — you need to know the area to buy enough paint. Or tiling a floor — you need to know the area to buy enough tiles. Area tells us how much surface a shape covers.

How do we measure area? With SQUARE UNITS! Cover this rectangle with square tiles, fitting them perfectly inside with no gaps and no overlaps. Count the tiles: 12! The area is 12 SQUARE UNITS. If we used 1-inch tiles, we say '12 square inches.' If we used 1-cm tiles, we say '12 square centimeters.'

Look at the tiles inside the rectangle. They form a grid: 3 rows of 4 tiles each. 3 x 4 = 12! That is the area formula: AREA = LENGTH x WIDTH. For a rectangle that is 5 units long and 2 units wide: 5 x 2 = 10 square units. For a square that is 4 x 4: 4 x 4 = 16 square units. Area uses MULTIPLICATION — our old friend!

slides.prompt: Find the area of each rectangle: 1) Cover with tiles and count: a 3x5 rectangle (should be 15 sq units). 2) Use the formula: a 6x4 rectangle (6 x 4 = 24 sq units). 3) On graph paper, draw rectangles with areas of exactly 12 square units (how many different rectangles can you make? 1x12, 2x6, 3x4!). 4) Measure a book cover in inches and calculate its area. Compare the PERIMETER and AREA of the same rectangle — they are different numbers!

slides.text: Area and perimeter are related but different! Perimeter measures the EDGE (distance around), and area measures the SPACE INSIDE. Perimeter uses addition; area uses multiplication. Both are essential in the real world: builders need both to construct a house. You now understand both concepts — that is powerful mathematical thinking!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child find the area of a rectangle by counting square units AND by using the formula length x width, and distinguish area from perimeter?

parent_notes: Area is a natural extension of both measurement and multiplication. The tile-counting approach makes it concrete before introducing the formula. The 'how many rectangles have area 12?' challenge is excellent because it reinforces factor pairs (1x12, 2x6, 3x4) while building area understanding. The area-perimeter distinction often confuses students: perimeter is a length (measured in units like inches) while area is a surface (measured in square units like square inches). Reinforce this distinction whenever possible. Real-world applications abound: how many tiles for the bathroom? How much carpet for the bedroom?

title: The Middle Ages — End of the Era and Bridge to Exploration
description: Students learn about the events that ended the Middle Ages: the Black Death, the Hundred Years War, the printing press, and the fall of Constantinople. They see how these events set the stage for the Age of Exploration in Quarter 3.
instructions:
1. Explain: the Middle Ages ended gradually, not suddenly.
2. Describe the Black Death (1347-1351): killed 1/3 of Europe, changed society.
3. Describe the printing press (1450): Gutenberg's invention spread knowledge.
4. Describe the fall of Constantinople (1453): forced Europeans to find new trade routes.
5. Preview: these changes led to the Age of Exploration!
6. Create a timeline of ending events.
7. Reflect: What was most important about the Middle Ages?
materials_needed: Images of the printing press and medieval events

slides.heading: The End of the Middle Ages
slides.subheading: Events That Changed the World Forever

items: Images of the Black Death, Gutenberg's printing press, and fall of Constantinople
slides.setup_instructions: Mark key dates on the timeline: 1347 (Black Death arrives), 1450 (printing press), 1453 (fall of Constantinople), 1492 (Columbus). Prepare to discuss these events age-appropriately.

slides.text: The Middle Ages lasted about 1,000 years, but three events between 1347 and 1453 changed Europe forever and brought the era to an end. These events were devastating, but they also opened the door to a new age of exploration, science, and art.

The BLACK DEATH (1347-1351): A terrible disease (plague) swept through Europe, killing about one-third of the entire population — 25 million people! It was carried by fleas on rats. The result was shocking: so many workers died that the survivors could demand better pay and treatment. The feudal system began to crumble because peasants had more power.

The PRINTING PRESS (around 1450): Johannes Gutenberg invented a press with movable metal type. Before this, every book was copied BY HAND (by our friends the monks!). Gutenberg's press could produce hundreds of copies quickly and cheaply. Suddenly, knowledge spread like wildfire! More people could learn to read. Ideas traveled faster than ever.

The FALL OF CONSTANTINOPLE (1453): Constantinople (modern Istanbul) was the gateway for trade between Europe and Asia. When it fell to the Ottoman Empire, European traders could no longer easily reach Asia for spices, silk, and gold. This forced Europeans to find NEW routes — by sea! This desperate search led directly to the AGE OF EXPLORATION, which we will study in Quarter 3!

slides.prompt: Create a timeline of the events that ended the Middle Ages: 1347 (Black Death), 1450 (printing press), 1453 (fall of Constantinople), 1492 (Columbus). For each event, draw a small illustration and write 2 sentences explaining its importance. Then write a paragraph: 'The Most Important Thing About the Middle Ages Was...' Choose ONE contribution (cathedrals, guilds, preserved knowledge, etc.) and defend your choice.

slides.text: The Middle Ages gave us cathedrals, universities, guilds, the preservation of ancient knowledge, and the foundations of modern European culture. Its ending — through plague, printing, and trade disruption — created the conditions for the most dramatic era of exploration in human history. Everything is connected! Quarter 3 will take us across the oceans with daring explorers.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child describe 3 events that ended the Middle Ages and explain how the fall of Constantinople led to the Age of Exploration?

parent_notes: This lesson wraps up the medieval unit and previews the Age of Exploration. The Black Death is a sensitive topic — present it factually and age-appropriately, emphasizing the societal changes it caused rather than dwelling on graphic details. The printing press is one of history's most important inventions; compare it to the internet in terms of knowledge-spreading impact. The connection between Constantinople's fall and the Age of Exploration is crucial: when the land route to Asia closed, Europeans were motivated to find sea routes — leading to Columbus, Magellan, and the dramatic changes of the 1500s.

title: Sound — Musical Instruments and How They Work
description: Students apply their knowledge of sound, pitch, and volume to understand how real musical instruments produce sound. They classify instruments into families (strings, woodwinds, brass, percussion) and explain the science behind each.
instructions:
1. Review: vibrations, pitch (frequency), volume (amplitude).
2. Introduce the four instrument families.
3. Strings: vibrating strings (guitar, violin) — length and thickness affect pitch.
4. Woodwinds: vibrating air column (recorder, flute) — length of tube affects pitch.
5. Brass: vibrating lips + tube (trumpet) — tube length affects pitch.
6. Percussion: vibrating surface (drum, xylophone) — size affects pitch.
7. Classify instruments and explain the science.
8. Record in science journal.
materials_needed: Images of instruments from each family

slides.heading: Musical Instruments
slides.subheading: The Science of Making Music

items: Images of instruments: guitar, violin, flute, recorder, trumpet, drum, xylophone, piano
Rubber band guitar from earlier experiments
slides.setup_instructions: Display images of instruments grouped by family. Have the recorder and rubber band guitar available for demonstration. If any family members play instruments, have those available too. Prepare a classification chart template.

slides.text: Every musical instrument creates sound through VIBRATIONS. But different instruments make different THINGS vibrate! This is how we classify the four instrument FAMILIES: strings (vibrating strings), woodwinds (vibrating air), brass (vibrating lips + air), and percussion (vibrating surfaces).

STRING INSTRUMENTS: Guitar, violin, cello, harp, piano (yes, piano has strings inside!). Strings vibrate when plucked, bowed, or struck. PITCH changes by: string length (shorter = higher), string thickness (thinner = higher), and string tightness (tighter = higher). Your rubber band guitar demonstrates all three!

WOODWIND INSTRUMENTS: Recorder, flute, clarinet, oboe. Air vibrates inside a tube. PITCH changes by changing the length of the vibrating air column — when you cover holes on the recorder, you lengthen the column (lower pitch). When you uncover holes, you shorten it (higher pitch). That is why more fingers down = lower notes!

BRASS: Trumpet, trombone, tuba. The player's lips vibrate and the sound is amplified by the metal tube. A trombone changes pitch by sliding the tube longer (lower) or shorter (higher). PERCUSSION: Drums, xylophone, cymbals. Something is struck and vibrates. Bigger drums = lower pitch. Smaller xylophone bars = higher pitch. Same principle as everything else!

slides.prompt: Create an instrument classification chart in your science journal. Draw four columns: Strings, Woodwinds, Brass, Percussion. For each family: list 3 instruments, draw one, and explain what vibrates and how pitch is changed. Then answer: 1) Why does a bass guitar sound lower than a regular guitar? 2) Why does covering more holes on a recorder make a lower sound? 3) Why is a tuba lower than a trumpet?

slides.text: Every instrument in the world, from a simple drum to a grand piano, works on the same scientific principles: vibrations create sound, vibration speed determines pitch, and vibration size determines volume. Music and science are deeply connected — understanding the physics makes you a better musician, and loving music makes science more beautiful!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child classify instruments into 4 families, explain what vibrates in each, and describe how pitch is changed for 3 different instruments?

parent_notes: This lesson ties together the entire sound unit by applying physics to music. If any family members play instruments, having them demonstrate while the child explains the science is powerful. The piano is interesting because it fits TWO categories: strings (hammers hit strings inside) and percussion (keys are struck). The recorder connection is direct: the child has been changing pitch by covering holes — now they understand the physics behind it. Consider attending a live concert or watching an orchestra performance video to see all four families in action.

title: Quarter 2 Art Showcase — Displaying and Reflecting on Art
description: Students curate a mini art exhibition of their best work from Quarter 2 (Greek pottery, illuminated letters, stained glass, watercolor landscapes, coat of arms). They learn to display art thoughtfully and write artist statements reflecting on their creative journey.
instructions:
1. Gather all art projects from Quarter 2.
2. Select 4-5 best pieces for the exhibition.
3. Create labels: title, medium, date, and a short artist statement.
4. Arrange the exhibition on a wall or table.
5. Write an overall reflection: How has your art improved?
6. Give a gallery tour to family members.
7. Celebrate creative growth!

slides.heading: Quarter 2 Art Showcase
slides.subheading: Your Gallery Exhibition

items: All Quarter 2 art projects: Greek pottery design, illuminated letter, stained glass window, watercolor landscape, coat of arms, mosaic, any instrument designs
Index cards or small paper for labels
Tape, pushpins, or stands for display
slides.setup_instructions: Gather all art from Q2. Help the child choose a display location: a wall, a table, a shelf. Prepare index cards for labels. Plan the gallery tour — invite family members to attend.

slides.text: Artists display their work in GALLERIES and EXHIBITIONS. Today you curate YOUR OWN art show! A curator selects the best pieces, arranges them thoughtfully, and writes information for viewers. Look through all the art you created this quarter. You have been busy — Greek pottery, illuminated letters, stained glass, watercolors, and more!

Select your 4-5 BEST pieces. For each one, create a label card with: the TITLE, the MEDIUM (what you used: watercolor, paper, markers), the DATE you made it, and a short ARTIST STATEMENT (1-2 sentences about what inspired you or what you learned making it).

Arrange your exhibition. Group related pieces together (medieval art near medieval history, Greek art near Greek history). Leave space between pieces so each one can be appreciated. Put labels next to or below each piece. Step back and look at the whole exhibition — this represents weeks of creative work!

slides.prompt: Set up your exhibition. Write labels for each piece. Then write a 'Curator's Reflection' in your journal: 1) Which piece are you most proud of and why? 2) What new art skill did you learn this quarter? 3) How has your art improved from the beginning to the end of Q2? 4) What do you want to create in Q3? Give a gallery tour to at least one family member, explaining each piece and its connection to what you learned.

slides.text: Your art exhibition celebrates a quarter of creative growth. Every piece tells a story — of ancient civilizations, medieval faith, the science of sound, and your own developing artistic vision. Art is how humans express what words cannot. Keep creating, keep experimenting, and keep sharing your work with the world!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child curate a thoughtful exhibition, write artist statements, articulate their creative growth, and present their work to an audience?

parent_notes: The art showcase is a meaningful way to end the quarter. It validates the child's creative work, develops communication skills (presenting to an audience), and builds self-reflection habits. Be a genuine, interested audience during the gallery tour — ask questions about the pieces and express specific praise ('I love how you used warm colors in the watercolor' rather than just 'nice job'). Consider photographing the exhibition and the child presenting it. Some families turn this into a tradition: quarterly art shows with refreshments. The artist statement writing connects to language arts skills.
